comments.commentBody: This really represents a fundamental misconception about evolution.  It's not that rationality evolved for the purpose of winning arguments.  Rather, rationality evolved completely by chance, and the reason that it stuck and eventually became dominant is because it gave some advantage to the people who had it, namely, according to this article, the advantage of winning arguments.  This would have helped the people with reason to survive over the others.  Now would someone mind telling me how the ability to win arguments helped some people survive while others without reason died off?  It doesn't make sense.  As terrible as your life is if you can't win an argument, I don't think that people die because of it.

The Internet has brought to life the idea of "short-lived fads". Read Slow Tuesday Night, by RA Lafferty, available here: http://themorningoil.blogspot.com/2010/03/slow-tuesday-night.html

The story was published in 1965, and still resonates 46 years later. An incredibly prescient story, in 2011, it suggests an Internet operating at Warp Factor 1000.

The essay and the comments point to a good starting point:  try to seperate the issues of philosphy from the issues that are potentially analytic.  There is a general but not universal concensus that the rate of growth of most socially supported medical spending (Medicare and tax subsidized below 65 care) should be reduced.  If the rate of growth is reduced who would benefit and would be hurt.  Relative to Medicare, premium support models with a strictly limited rate of voucher growth would do at least three things:  Increase insurance adminstrative costs; increase out of pocket spending; greatly increase the difference between treatment options for the financially well off and those less well off; reduce the income of physicans, hospitals and other medically providers; reduce the expansion of medical technology available to treat conditions primarily age related; reduce transfers from the non-aged to the aged population.

#269 - What makes him think - as so many other "believers" do - that quoting the mummery is some kind of proof hat faith is not subjective? The mummery only makes any sense to those who already DO believe. To a nonbeliever, it's just ancient claptrap.

Using mummery to prove the "truth" of mummery is essentially an act of irrationality. People think that all those "thees and thous" are awesome proof. A REAL religion wouldn't need any mummery - "holy writ" - at ALL. It could say all that really needs to be said in, maybe, two paragraphs. If that much. And there once WAS such a thing - it wasn't a religion, though, but a spirituality. Which is worlds different from religions, which are constructs made by people who want a means of controlling vast numbers of people. Spirituality didn't judge or moralize. Those things were for humans to work out for themselves. No "holy writ," no judgment days or armageddons (i.e., raptures for sadists who want to watch people barbecued), no moralizing, no hierarchies and internal political setups. And no proselytizing. It lasted over 15,000 years, too. It was very fulfilling and people were content with it. Until a bunch of Hebrews decided they wanted a MALE god, instead of the Earth Mother.

What they did was to genocide believers in the Earth Mother, to stamp it out. They almost succeeded. They endowed their new god with male attributes - the ugly ones. Their god was a god to FEAR. The Earth Mother was a god to LOVE. We can thank those Hebrews for royally messing up the world.

A god who is slathering to send people into a fiery pit is not exactly a loving god. You can't have it both ways. This particular god is more judgmental than I would ever be. If I were a god, with all that omnipotence and omniscience, I wouldn't be sadistic the way this god is supposed to be. It would be hard to send ANYONE into a fire. Guess I'm nicer than that god, huh?

They are also migrating to the southeast. Today there was a dead one in the street at 1st Street and 7th Avenue. And today I saw one ran across the sidewalk on 7th Avenue between Carroll and Garfield Streets.

I'm one of 8. I have a tolerable relationship with most of my surviving siblings (6). Minimal relationship with a couple. Unfortunately. We all got along better as adults (age range now 55-38), but many of those old childhood issues never went away. Though my parents did their best, they assumed forcing the relationship would make it happen (my mom is very close with her 2 sisters, my father had a conflicted, but close relationship, with his 10 siblings).

I have read and re-read the book "Siblings Without Rivalry" as I raise my 2 (18 months and 5). I have numerous friends who, as adults, are very close to their siblings as well as friends whose teenage children are very close. I know it can happen. I pray it will for my kids. In life I want many things for them, but mostly, I want them to have each other to turn to as adults, to share their past and their future.

I must say, Mr. Cavett, that I haven't had the time or the inclination to read your past columns recently until today, being caught up, as it were, in the tangled web of intrigue that appears to my eyes via the Internet at Facebook these days.  I did notice, however, that I am unable to access those past columns written before the first of this year.  So, needing respite today from concerns more important to me, such as good government and the apparent censorship of a certain book on my favorites list from the '80's, I decided to give your most recent column a read.  Unfortunately, you lost me somewhere around the first or second paragraph, since I am almost completely illiterate about the theatre.  The only connection I have had to Broadway or theatre was a drama class in 9th grade - "Four Frightened  Sisters" and "It's Cold in Them Thar Hills!"  Those, and a couple of community theatre presentations with my mother and a good friend of hers who taught military psychology at the community college.  Oh, and of course "Big River" at the Starlight Theatre in Kansas City, Missouri.  Shoot.  I don't even know the answer to a simple Laddergrams puzzle I was working earlier this afternoon:  What's a four letter word for a Broadway show sponsor, using four of the five letters k, a, e, r, and b?  Now I have to go call the attorney who was supposed to represent me in a late 2004 involuntary commitment so that I can obtain the medication I need to ease my paranoid schizophrenia when I need it.  (Insanity runs in my family.  It practically gallops.)  All the best to you and your's, and I'll keep checking back impatiently for your next column.
Now, more than Ever, We LOVE NEW YORK ~ Let Freedom RING!

Greetings from the LGBTQQI Capital of the World, where we can only look on admiringly and hope that someday our state joins New York and the others in granting full civil rights to our communities!  We'll celebrate your beautiful victory from afar during this historic Pride Weekend in SF & NYC.

I add my voice to the ecstatic chorus tonight.  A thousand -- no, a million -- cheers for the senators who kept their minds open, wrestled with their consciences, and voted yes. We'll have your backs when you need us.

It is almost 8 years after gay marriage was recognized in Ontario and 6 years after it was recognized nationally.It has strengthened relationships and family values.'I do' means the same whether you are gay or straight.Happy pride to all New yorkers.
My happiness is bittersweet -- of the couple I love who would've been able to marry, one did not live to see it.

Proud to be a New Yorker, and even more impressed that Albany could put party politics aside to vote on this important issue. Why can't Republicans in the US Senate/House do this with any other important national issue?

I've seen Portland games on TV and it seems like a great big party in the stands, even in pouring rain storms!
There's something about soccer that brings out the worst in people in many places around the world, I saw it growing up in northern England, drunken fights were commonplace, it's an old problem but hopefully that never happens in the MLS.

I'm so happy about this!!! It's wonderful, wonderful news, but I still dream of the day when all committed and loving gay or lesbian couples can marry everywhere!!Hoping by the time it's legal in my state, maybe I will have found my true love!:) In the meanwhile, there aren't enough words to express my joy for those lucky enough to have found love and now be able to marry the person they can't imagine living the rest of their life without...

So for Anderson and his fellow clan-member, go for it! Formalize a "civil union." Quite pestering the world with your demand for acquiescence to your definition of "normalcy." A coincidence that President Obama was to be in NYC? His polls are so poor he would kiss a pig for a vote if Axelrod gave the order.
All the votes in the universe will not make it right. Legal but not right.

Say what you like about the Republican party, but the four who decided to stop wasting everyone's time and money defending what is not ultimately going to be constitutionally defensible are winners. And a whole lot better than our President who can only muster a "stop defending" it reactive stance, rather than a proactive, supportive stance.
I am so happy that common sense has prevailed in government. Might we be seeing a bit of the old Republican party rearing it's head? A party of common sense and long term planning vs a party of religious nut jobs who have no business being in government? That would be nice. And might get my vote.
So happy that my sister will be able to finally legally marry the woman that we have acknowledged as her wife for over three years now.

Great news. I look forward to the day when people around the country scratch their heads and say, "Remember when gays weren't allowed to get married? What were we thinking back then?". Congrats to all who worked so hard for passage of the bill.

There was no way my husband, Mark, and I and our daughters were going to miss tonight's vote, live, in person.  What a privilege to be in the gallery when the world changed.  Governor Cuomo needs to be President.

Congratulations to all New York citizens, including their leaders, for correctly, appropriately,and publicly celebrating beauty, love, inclusiveness, peace, and tolerance. This also shows that Americans and humans everywhere can change, giving us all hope for the future of the Earth.

Thank you Andrew Cuomo for opening your heart to Marriage Equality, and your persistence. Senator Grisanti
you're a hero. I recommend to anyone who believes their Christian faith precludes supporting Marriage Equality to read John Boswell's "Christianity, Social Tolerance, and Homosexuality" which I believe has planted the seeds for a flowering of acceptance of gay people in Christian churches the world over.
Millions of gay people the world over are closer to being able to love fully and honestly.

I wouldn't worry about the caterers. Assuming that gay people will want a Viennese Dessert Table at their wedding as much as straight people, caterers will be happy to oblige. Gay, bisexual, transgender, or straight:  Money is money!
